SEARCH
Package gw.api.observability

Class ObservabilityContext

java.lang.Object
gw.api.observability.ObservabilityContext
public class ObservabilityContext extends Object

A set of configurations specific to a single usage of ObservabilityPlugin to communicate what the plugin should include in any log messages or metrics it sends.

This class is meant to be extensible in a non-breaking way. Therefore, anything added to this class in the future should be completely optional, OR this class should be extended. There is also no guarantee that any plugin implementation will use any or all of the settings present, so interdependencies between these settings should be kept to a minimum.

Currently, the context available through this object are as follows:

  • Use withContext(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object) to store context to be used in log messages. It serves almost the same purpose as LogMessageParams, except that it is also used by metric tags as described below.
  • Use withMetricTagContextKey(java.lang.String) to store keys which will be used as tags for any metrics sent to DataDog or otherwise. Metrics always consist of a key-value pair, where the values are taken from custom context (above).
  • Use withMessage(java.lang.String) to store the message to be included in any logs generated by the plugin.
  • Use withLogging(boolean) to communicate to the plugin whether the plugin should log (default true) or not.
  • Use withStartTime(java.lang.Long, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit) to store the actual start time to be used in calculating the ElapsedTime of a process. Please review the documentation for withStartTimeNs(java.lang.Long).
More information can be found in the docs for each of these fields' setters.

    • withMetricTagContextKey

      public ObservabilityContext withMetricTagContextKey(@Nonnull String key)
      Add a key which will be used as a metric tag. The tag's value is determined by _context's values. If the key is not present in _context, its value is 'null'.
      Parameters:
      key - A key which will be used for a metric tag.

    • withContext

      public ObservabilityContext withContext(@Nonnull String key, Object value)

      Add the given key and value to this object's _context, used both for log messages and for metric tags using withMetricTagContextKey(java.lang.String).

      Using this method in combination with withMetricTagContextKey(java.lang.String) can be done in one step with withContextAndMetricTagContextKey(java.lang.String, java.lang.Object).

      Parameters:
      key - The context key.
      value - The context value.
      Returns:
      this

    • getCustomStartTimeNs

      public Long getCustomStartTimeNs()

    • withStartTimeNs

      public ObservabilityContext withStartTimeNs(Long startTime)

      Use the given start time (in nanoseconds) as an override to the ObservabilityPlugin's calculation of ElapsedTime.

      The intended use for this context is for when the beforeProcessStart and afterProcessComplete calls are expected to occur on different threads.

      Note that for any implementation which uses the ObservabilityLogger, setting a start time effectively requires the user to send the same startTime when calling one of ObservabilityPlugin.afterProcessComplete(java.lang.String) or ObservabilityPlugin.onProcessFail(java.lang.String, java.lang.String).

      The reverse is also true: If the start time is not set, the user should also not set it when calling the complete or failure method.

      Note that currently, there is no way to set a stop time in the same way. It is always calculated on-the-spot when calling the complete or failure method. Also note that the DataDogReporter will not track spans for those functions which use this method, since this method will also mark _shouldEmitSpan false.

      Parameters:
      startTime - The start time of the process.
      Returns:
      this

    • withEpochBasedStartTimeNs

      public ObservabilityContext withEpochBasedStartTimeNs(Long startTime)

      Use the given epoch-based start time (in nanoseconds) as an override to the ObservabilityPlugin's calculation of ElapsedTime.

      The intended use for this context is for when the beforeProcessStart and afterProcessComplete calls are expected to occur on different threads. This call assumes that the start time provided will by the nanoseconds since the epoch. In contrast to the withStartTimeNs method which only take a number of nanos from System.nanoTime() which just gives a arbitrary number of nanos that is only suitable for comparison with a later call to get an interval of nanos. Use this method when providing a start time derived from a real datetime, such as a message sendtime. The system will use this to calculate a difference in nanos when reporting duration.

      Note that for any implementation which uses the ObservabilityLogger, setting a start time effectively requires the user to send the same startTime when calling one of ObservabilityPlugin.afterProcessComplete(java.lang.String) or ObservabilityPlugin.onProcessFail(java.lang.String, java.lang.String).

      The reverse is also true: If the start time is not set, the user should also not set it when calling the complete or failure method.

      Note that currently, there is no way to set a stop time in the same way. It is always calculated on-the-spot when calling the complete or failure method. Also note that the DataDogReporter will not track spans for those functions which use this method, since this method will also mark _shouldEmitSpan false.

      Parameters:
      startTime - The start time of the process.
      Returns:
      this
